review_blob: bottle into a tulip. Dark coppery brown, thin head, minimal lacing. Aroma of caramel, vanilla plus rum & raisins. Taste is medium sweet with an aftertaste of rum coming through. Nice beer, a little fancy, but not super fancy.

bottle into a tulip glass. Dark with an instant (but not overwhelmingly strong) aroma of coffee and chocolate. I love my dark, sweet, malty beers and this didnt disappoint . Pretty well made porter. Not as thick and chewy as a stout, but still packed full of flavour. Medium length palate, with a nice mocha finish 
Great beer - expect you will be happy if you like porters, as it is a good interpretation of the style.

bottle into glass. Not sure if I was just anticipating something fantastic or didnt take into account the "new world" part of the marketing, but it was a let down. Just wasnt what I expected of an ESB. No dark fruits, no raisins, no malt. Plenty of bitterness (not a bad thing) and big piney, citrus aroma. More like a half way between an Australian Pale Ale and an IPA. 
So it was an OK beer, but if you think of ESB as being like an English dark ale then you might be disappointed. I might have enjoyed it more if I was in the mood for an APA

500ml bottle into glass. Huge Aroma of citrus, pine and passionfruit. Dark side of amber with a lively foam - be careful when you pour. Head holds fairly well but not forever and produces a mild lacing. Amazing taste with massive levels of sweet malts with a back end of hop bitterness. The kind of beer you want to hold and gentle move around your mouth a few times to extract every last drop of flavour. Carbonation is lively and threatens to make the texture thin, yet the chewy malts resist and it ends up fine. Improved as it warmed slightly. No hint at all of the high alcohol. Overall a big beer with complexity, one of the better Imperial IPAs being produced in Australia and by far the best beer 4 Pines have in their stable (so far).

Bottle poured into glass. Mild tropical scent overlayed with (thye say floral - but I couldnt find the right words to describe it) with other aromas. Dark brown (the only way this is burnt orange is if you say VERY burnt orange). Nice taste of sweet malts first before the hop bitterness kicks in - but not too bitter. Pretty good mix. Enjoyed.

500ml can into a glass. Strong aroma, but despite all the marketing to the contrary it wasnt balanced. Not bad, but not great. The hops whilst bitter didnt really provide much complexity and the malts were hardly there. The bitterness overwhelms the palate leaving no room to taste much else. Carbonation and mouthfeel were good. Good effort, but there are far, far better Imperial IPAs out there with more complexity in both the hop characteristics and malt profiles. But, hey its beer - drink what YOU like.

Basically identical to the Hefeweizen. So almost the exact same review bar one word. "clear" instead of "Cloudy"
500ml bottle into a weizen. Clear yellowish orange, loose white head which didnt last. Aroma is faint and almost non existent. Reasonably carbonated and sweetish. Hints of banana at the end. OK, but not special.

500ml bottle into a weizen. Cloudy yellowish orange, loose white head which didnt last. Aroma is faint and almost non existent. Reasonably carbonated and sweetish. Hints of banana at the end. OK, but not special.

500ml bottle into a weizen glass. Mild aroma mostly suppressed by the fluffy head. More aroma from the bottle - typical banana yeast. Slightly cloudy amber with a large head which fell away quickly. Taste is mostly hidden by carbonation but it is sweetish with a tanginess / hint of late mild bitterness at the end. Mouthfeel is OK and palate is medium length. Overall nice but not great.

500ml bottle into a weizen glass. Thick pillowy white foam - three fingers (must pour carefully). Foam held for a while but disappeared quicker than I had hoped . Minimal lacing. Golden hazy colour. Aroma subdued - possibly pear? Something there but faint. Excellent mouthfeel with a long palate and lingering taste of banana lollies. Mimimal bitterness (as per the style), but not too sweet. Had been drinking guinness earlier in the day and this is a welcome change (several hours break in between). Not my favourite - but still very good. Would welcome a glass any time
500ml bottle. Straw gold. Well carbonated, good crisp clean mouthfeel and palate. Good for the style - just not my favourite style. But for a hot day or BBQ with mild seafoods - all good.

500ml bottle (green) into a nonic pint glass. Someone else said Mahogany in colour and I agree. Nice aroma but not strong, of raisins, caramel and toffee. Tastes mostly sweet and the tang of raisins / sultanas comes through at the end of the drink. Nice drop, but there are better out there and redder out there. Ive had one - so I can say I have - and if offered would say "yes please" - but I wouldnt race out for my next, as there are better in the style to have first (and at a better price too).

750ml bottle (use by August 2017) poured into a snifter (several times). 
I wasnt a blonde fan, but I must say I am a fan of strong belgian ale. The aroma was average but it poured a beautiful foamy golden colour and retained the head (until my wife came along and pinched it). Really hard to describe the flavour as it is subtle and complex with multiple textures and essences coming through and staying on the tongue well after the mouthful is finished. (i.e. a long palate).
It didnt blow me away as much as snuck up on me until I realised I REALLY wanted more, but the bottle had run out. 
Very expensive here in Oz: $16 for the one bottle, but I will but it again for a special occasion. It is worth it.
Very nice indeed!

Really happy with my first two beers, very disappointed with the second two. 
So I will rate on the first two and assume something was wrong with the second batch. 
Two 330ml bottles poured into a 660ml plus weizen glass.
Not much of an aroma, and missing the banana scent associated with bavarian wheat beers. Dont get the citrus much either. Light golden colour reminiscent of a macro larger. Head poured lower than expected and then fell away even quicker. Some lacing on glass, loads of bubbles coming up the centre. 
Taste was moderate sweetness and light bitterness. 
Palate is confusing in that if you sip - it comes across watery, but with a decent mouthful it has a creaminess as you swirl it around in your mouth. Very short on palate length which is a blessing. 
Comparatively this is to a Hefeweizen what a (good) light beer is to a larger - almost right, but somehow just not quite the full deal.
Buy a Victus and be happy instead.
Easy drinking well flavoured beer. Right balance of malt alcohol and hops.

Bottle, poured into pilsner glass. As much as I wanted to, I couldnt really warm to this one. Really hard to label the nose, or taste, but I do know I just didnt really like it - not to my taste.
So rated it average as Im sure others will like it and I cant criticise it too much as it was brewed well, but just wasnt my cup of tea in regards to flavours.

What has happened to Monteiths. First, they did well. Then they got greedy and trademarked Radler so no one else in NZ could use it (like the invented it - not); then they produce shite like this and trade on their previous good name.
Even the commercial deScription of this beer is bad - saying nothing about the beer - just why they gave it the name they did. American Pale ales are big hoppy - this isnt and has a sweetish corn syrup after taste. Rubbish.
They should have never tarnished their reputation by releasing such a poor quality product.

Bottle poured into a snifter glass. I was really looking forward to this, but it didnt live up the hype. Dark beer, tan head, reasonably frothy - so appearance good. Aroma was dark fruits and chocolate - also good. Taste and palate - thin, lifeless and lacking flavour. Where is the big chewy, creamy mouthfeel you expect from a milk stout. Where is the sweetness, the malts, the cocoa and warmth - All missing - so below average on taste and palate. No smoke despite the lable saying otherwise (and yes, I did drink at around 12 degrees celsius). 
So overall below par. I dont really care if a beer looks good or smells great (they do help overall enjoyment) because the taste is the boss. 
Nice try guys, keep at it - the beer promised much upfront, just didnt deliver all the way to the end.
beer_name: Beard and Brau Black Snout Milk Stout

review_blob:
Bottle, poured into stein. 
Simple beer and very easy to drink. Nice malty flavor, biscuit, bread, caramel. Minimal bitterness, but nicely balanced sweetness. Not my go to beer, but happy to drink this at any festival.

355ml bottle. Enjoy by 13 July 2016. Stemmed glass. 
Wow, after assaulting the nose, this beer grabs the tongue with two full hands of hops and then hangs on, long after the liquid has hit the gullet. Aroma clearly of tropical fruits and pine. Pineapple, mango, and piney. Golden to pale yellow. My beer was exceptionally frothy. Flavour was all upfront hops and then lingering bitterness. Then you realise it tastes just like grapefruit. Now dont let that put you off, as I dont like grapefruit, but his is amazing. It has all the tang and bitterness of a grapefruit, but somehow manages to still be nice. Its like there is a hint of another citrus fruit that just saves it from being too tart. So this beer is light on sweetness, big on bitterness with a finish on sour and a hint of salty at the end. 
Im a malt guy, but this is a Wow beer. Too big for larger lovers, but if you are after a hop hit - this is right up there. 
The beer is also 4.5% but comes across bigger and slightly alcohol hot.
Just way too expensive by the time it gets to Australia. $7 a bottle or $30 for a full six pack.

500ml Bottle. Craft beer glass. Shared with friend. Ohhhh, this is a big beer. Aroma is less than expected, and I cant get the pineapple scent as advertised, but plenty of resin and tropical fruit salad is there. But then chewy matls (first time Ive ever described a beer as chewy) followed by a big hit of sweet-ish hops. Bitterness comes through, but not at the 90 IBU level for me - which was good. Medium length finish on the palate, which is what held it back from a five - great mouth feel. The carbonation was just right to give a meaty, fat mouthful whilst still enabling a good white and reasonable lasting head. Limited lacing, but the head did persist until the end. The more I drank the better it got too. Shame it is a limited edition otherwise Id keep one in the fridge perpetually just to surprise a friend on how complex and big a beer can be at the same time, or for when Im bored with the usual stuff.
This is just a FUN beer. 
Nice job 4 Pines - I tip my hat to you.
beer_name: 4 Pines Keller Door Series Imperial IPA

review_blob:
330ml bottle as part of six pack. Shaker glass. Deep dark brown with a tan head that doesnt last. Rich sweet warm biscuit aroma and sweet taste. Dont drink too cold or you will bypass the flavour. Great with an indian curry like tikka masala, but also good on its own. Good creamy mouthfeel with the a cleansing carbonation at the end. Medium palate, quite sweet to finish with just a hint of cleansing bitterness. Made by the crew at Little Creatures (now part of Lion) so it had to be good. 
Note: Too often served too cold at a bar. Chilled is good, ice cold not, warm not good either.

On tap, Newstead Brewing - however this version had spent 2 years in Shiraz casks. Smokey flavour had reduced to nothing, but there was a rose hue to the beer and a more floral aroma. Hints of the shiraz coming in late on the palate. Really well balanced with no alcohol burn at all at 9%+. 
Brilliant.

Pot from tap. Wow. Great stout and low alcohol too (for a stout). Salted part was mild and came in at the end for me. Otherwise a full flavoured great looking black as ink stout with a tan coloured head. Foam lasted all the way to the end. Aroma was low and barely discernable but the flavour was there in full chorus. Moderate and silky mouthfeel. Moderate length of palate - lasting a few seconds after drinking but not one of those that you will be tasting all night. Very, very happy with this beer. Just didnt kick goals on the aroma, but Id rather have a beer that tasted good and had no nose than the other way around.

500ml bottle into nonic glass. Aroma of toffee, raisins and dark red fruits. Dark amber, clear with limited carbonation and a cream coloured head. Sweetish, but with a metallic finish - otherwise would have rated higher - but not much more at the palate was thinner than others I have had. Good overall - but have other brands I would turn to first for an ESB.

550ml bottle into a glass. Great aroma of toffee and raisins but didnt get the nuts that was promised. Could easily be me. Dark reddish hue with an off white heading towards tan. Flavour was lighter than expected and middle of the road. Minimal sweetness and far less malty or nutty than expected. Plate was a bit weak and short. Expected better.

750ml bottle poured (several times) into a snifter glass. Delicious. Aroma from the bottle is divine toffee, caramel malty essence. Similar from glass, but scent is subdued due to the large slightly off white / beige foam. Dark murky brown colour. Appearance suffered simply because the head didnt hold as well as expected. Reasonable lacing. Taste is sweet and malty which nicely balances the high alcohol content. Palate was long and lingering. Overall an amazing beer. But I enjoyed the white more - will need to pay attention to the label and perhaps cellar for a while to get a better flavour profile as this bottle had been delivered to the store the day I purchased it.

330ml bottle as part of a four pack. Poured into a Hoegaarden glass. Nice nose with yeasty earthy tones. Appearance is of a very pale yellow. Taste - out of the four beers I felt I had two nice ones and two that werent (had over several days). Cant say what caused the difference, but two tasted highly carbonated and low on flavour with a metallic/sour aftertaste and the other two had more herb flavours, better mouthfeel and a long nice slightly sweet finish.

Green bottle into a shaker glass at a bar. What a pleasant surprise. Very sceptical about any beer in a green or clear bottle, but this had been stored well. Not much of an aroma (but it is a pilsner) so cant expect the same level as other styles, but there is a slight citrus note. Taste and palate were excellent for the style. Not complex but simplicity done well. Very light sweetness up front, then a medium to light bitterness kicking in to balance. You are left with a fresh cleansing and refreshing short finishing palate. Just nice. Simple but nice. Will have again but still wary of the green bottle - hope the next one is as fresh as the last.

Bottle into a Paulaner pilsner glass (hey - thats what the barman did). Golden amber colour. Limited aroma. Reasonable white head which held OK then eventually disappeared with no lacing. Taste - bitter, sharp and unpleasant. Real surprise and not in a good way. Left an unpleasant flavour on the back of the tongue afterwards. 
Just came back to add this comment after reading this was listed as an IPA. Not sure why. No hops feature and the label says sparking ale.

500ml swing top bottle poured into a nonic pint glass. Yellow with white foam head. Not much of an aroma at all. Bland flavour. Just nothing to let you know you were drinking a beer of quality. Tasted like... disappointment. Wasnt horrible by any means, just wasnt memorable. Palate medium but of almost nothing. First and only time I will have this - life is too short to experience this again when there are so many more complex beers on offer.

Bottle into a stemmed glass. Smells like an IPA, looks like porter with a mocha coloured head. Tastes like an IPA upfront followed by a malty and possibly even chocolatey stout at the end. Great mix of flavours and plenty of them. A little difficult to pick out individual flavours, but the mix works well. Bought a case for Christmas (note: only 16 x 330ml bottles to a case). Very nice beer that satisfies the desire for a dark beer at Christmas with the practicality of an IPA for the hot climate I live in.
Doubt you will be disappointed.

Bottle. Stemmed pilsner glass. Big hoppy aroma with a mix of pine and citrus. Amber colour - quite clear, not as clear as others - but couldnt call it cloudy. Average head that stuck around for a little while but not too long. Taste was big yet balanced. High alcohol at 7.2% but couldnt really tell. Some bitterness due to the hops but again balanced so you were left with a pleasant aftertaste. 
Good beer, maybe even a great beer.

500ml bottle. Nonic pint glass. Aroma of smoked meats, salami perhaps? Really nice and different. Not the campfire smoke they say, but nicer anyway. Low head which doesnt last long at all, and a deep dark still porter black, not quite opaque but close. Taste was only subtly smoked which works for me - if you are a big smoke person (and Im not) then you may be disappointed, but I loved it. Went well with dinner. Minimal sweetness, and minimal bitterness. More meaty or umami. Palate was typical porter medium with low carbonation and worked well with the flavours. 
Great beer and one that may have won me over to the smoke.
beer_name: Wolf of the Willows Johnny Smoke Porter

review_blob:
Bottle into a snifter.
Bourbon coloured with average frothy cream coloured head which lasted for a little while and did produce lacing. Aroma is subtle but complex with an unusual scent for a beer. Light caramel, or honey maybe maple syrup smell - but not sickly sweet, far too understated. Flavour is moderately sweet with long duration. Smooth is the word that came to mind whilst I drank it. Body is medium to full, texture is creamy, carbonation is soft.
This is a good sipping beer.

Bottle into a shaker glass.
Whoa Nelly! that is some big flavour. Pours a darkish almost red colour with a two finger off white / beige head. Foam hangs around and leaves great lacing. Smells like a pine and citrus forest with each overlapping the other. Flavour is big and bold. Light sweetness and then screaming loud hoppy bitterness all the way to the end with a lingering coppery note at the end. Was that the rye?
Wont be for everyone, but that is a hell of a beer, and one will see you through.

Bottle into a shaker glass. I dont know if sunlight got to this when it was imported, but this was unpleasant. Why oh why do brewers put beer in green bottles - especially for export?
Anyway. Light pale yellow with virtually no head, and then what foam was there completely disappeared. Completely. Smelled funky, but not not funky nice like Saison (well most saisons) this was funky strange - but not skunky. 
Taste was one dimensional and fairly crisp. Really dont want another.

Bottle poured into a nonic pint glass from the Three Little Pigs Tavern. Nice brown sugar coloured beer with a nose of light malt and toffee. I let the beer warm a little but really struggled to get a lot of flavour or aroma from the beer. Nursed it for over half an hour in the hope it would deliver something more. The flavour was nice, mostly sweet almost zero bitterness - but I just couldnt get any of the cinnamon, spice or blackcurrant stated on the label. 
So it was nice but at the same time disappointing. I kept wanting it to be bigger, but it came across a thin and weak for the style. Shame.
beer_name: Stone & Wood Forefathers Phil Sexton English Brown

review_blob: On tap. Nice beer. No where near as hoppy as the names suggests, but still very nice. Darkish amber, no cloudiness. with a one finger head that held fairly well and left moderate lacing. Nice aroma - but a little difficult to name - maybe resin?. Decent mouthfeel - not thin, not thick, you know you have a beer in your mouth. Good balance of malt and hops with both coming through at different times. The finish is slightly bitter with a brief but nice lingering taste, reasonably well rounded finish. Worth having again.
beer_name: James Squire Hop Thief 7 Galaxy & Mosaic Hops

review_blob: Bottle 355ml. Poured into a washington glass. Firstly, much different to when Ive had it on tap. Aroma was toffee. Appearance was of a flat beer - almost zero head which went to the faintest ring Ive ever experienced in a beer that wasnt completely flat. Toffee coloured to match the scent. Sweet tasting with toffee notes a little hint of fruit. Overall nice, but wasnt a match for what Id describe as a bitter.

Bottle 500ml. Poured into a nonic pint glass. Initially served too cold so aroma was suppressed. When it warmed up a little, the aroma was soft but smelled a little like fruitcake with brandy - but far more subtle. Very nice. Poured a deep ruby red / chestnut colour. Tight cream coloured foam, which was about a finger width and held nicely leaving lacing all the way down the glass. Fairly mild sweetness but full tasting. Silky, velvety smooth palate. Short to medium finish with the fruitcake flavour coming in again at the finish, followed by a hint of alcohol which adds to the boozy fruitcake feel. 
Definitely needs to be at the right temperature to appreciate properly. Didnt get half of what Ive written during the first half of the drink and it improved 500% as it warmed up. 
This is a must have repeat for me. Awesome beer. Wow!

330ml bottle into shaker glass. No Smell. No taste. This is the cheap vodka of beers - no flavour at all. Doesnt even taste like water. Doesnt taste like soda water. Just fizziness that slides off your tongue and leaves you wondering what just happened. Pale straw colour with infinitesimal head and no lacing. Reminds me of 1970s home brew. Utter rubbish.

Green bottle. Poured into a shaker. Dark straw (so still light / pale but not golden) pours with a one finger head which disappears almost immediately. No lacing at all. Smell is unpleasant. Not quiet skunk but not too far away. Taste is sweet - zero bitterness. Thankfully short finish. Not worth it.
Bottle into stemmed pilsner glass. Nice crisp clean golden orange beer. Light carbonation and uncomplex in flavour it still leaves you feeling good.

Beer from bottle in local pub. No glass. I was hoping this would be comparable to Hoegaarden (which I had been told it was) and I was sooo wrong. OK beer, but the flavour mix with orange and coriander just doesnt work as well. Cant tell you why - just doesnt. I have been back to pub many times and just cant take the plunge to order this again (about $9 a bottle here). I actually order a local macro beer on tap - enough said.

Straight from bottle. Another lawnmower beer. Refreshing when you are hot and wish to down something quickly. Cold filtered water though might do the trick even better. Also good to put six or so in the Esky when you have a large gathering as there is always someone who will prefer this to beer (who has never had anything other than a macro lager). E.g. me 15 years ago.

Bottle 500ml. Weizen glass. Aroma - slight banana flavour but oh so tempting. The three plus finger head stifles the nose somewhat. Clear and full of streaming bubbles. Amazing mouthfeel and delicious perfectly balanced mix of sweet beer flavour with virtually no bitterness. Flavour lingers on the tongue all the way until the next mouthful.

How can anyone who takes beer seriously put it in a green bottle when they KNOW it will skunk as soon as it sees the light of day. Especially a lightly flavoured beer like a lager. Should be a criminal offence. Anyway - I remembered this much more fondly than I do now after tasting again. Simple lager with clean crisp finish when it hasnt gone off in the bottle. Too hit and miss and too simple to waste time on having again. Lawn mowing beer at best.

Bottle. Clear yellow with small white head. Very weak aroma - might be a good thing. Fizzy carbonation. Sweet corn / grain taste - and not much else. Not particularly offensive. Not particularly anything. Dull experience. Would drink again if I was very thirsty or to be polite if someone offered me one. Otherwise would pass.

From bottle into tulip. Black with a foaming beige head. Soft aroma of toasted malts. Roasted malts upfront, medium carbonation to soften the impact and then something at the back - coffee? smoke? Not sure, but slightly bitter. Bitterness 
finishes fairly quickly and the malts reappear as they linger on the palate. Enjoyable mouthfeel - neither thin nor silky, just medium and right for the flavours. A good, highly drinkable beer - quite sessionable and the best of the style Ive had so far.
